loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies

location.town: San Vicente, Tambulig, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: M. Betty is a businesswoman who has operated a pub for, so far, ten years. She is thirty-eight years old and she has two children. She is using the loan to purchase more crates of drinks for her pub business to attract more customers. Her dream is to build permanent rental houses for income generation.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks for her pub to attract more customers

loans.name: Muhaiyo

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
Чабборова Мухайё женщина 38 лет. Замужем имеет 3-х детей. Мухайё занимается продажей продуктов и питание. У неё свой магазин который  находиться в центре джамоате Овчи-Калъача. Она берёт займ для того чтобы увеличит свой товарооборот и с помощью увеличит доходность семьи. Так как в семье никто не работает она открыло свой маленький бизнес. Ей помогает её муж Ахрор.
texts.en:
Muhaiyo C. is 38 years old, married and has 3 children. Mahaiyo sells food products. She has her own store, which is located in the center of djamoat Ovchi-Kal’acha. She is obtaining this loan in order to increase her goods turnover and to increase family income. Since no one else in the family works, she started her small business. Her husband, Ahror, helps Muhaiyo with the business.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food products

loans.name: Schola

texts.en:
Ms. K. Schola is a businesswoman, thirty-eight years old. She owns a retail shop near her residence in Kibuli. She is using the loan to purchase retail items such as Omo (a detergent brand), Blue Band (a margarine brand), sugar, salt, soap, flour, etc., to make a larger stock.

For more income generation, Ms. K. Schola wants to start up a salon as a side-business to her retail shop since she has hair skills. Her dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase more retail items to enlarge her stock

loans.name: Andrea

texts.en: Andrea U. is from the village of Santa Cruz, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental. She is 53 years old, married, and has five school-aged children. Andrea owns and operates a business making and selling food, primarily preparing and selling food in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over thirty years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Andrea joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC. Andrea is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Aziza

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
Азиза девушка - 28 лет. Не замужем образование неполное. Азиза занимается торговлей мужского белья. Товар привозит поставщик. Она оплачивает транспортные расходы и даёт деньги за товар иногда она сама ездит за товаром. Она торгует на рынке более 5 лет. Азиза накапливает деньги на приданное. Её родители также раньше торговали на рынке. С годами стало труднее и бизнес она взяла в свои руки.
texts.en:
Aziza is a 28-year-old young woman. She is single. Her education is incomplete. Aziza sells men’s undergarments. The supplier delivers the merchandise. Aziza pays for travel expenses and gives money for the merchandise, and sometimes travels for the merchandise herself. She has been selling at the market for over 5 years. Aziza is saving money for the dowry. Her parents used to sell at the market too. However, it became harder for them as they grew older, and Aziza took over the business.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of men's undergarments

loans.name: Sabougnouma 5 Group

texts.fr:
Sabougnouma 5 est constitué de femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 29 ans, 2 enfants et  vivant la plupart dans des familles polygames à Djambougou  un des villages de la commune rurale de Tingolé, sous préfecture de Fana, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités hivernales. Les spéculations sont l’arachide et le petit mil. Elles sont à leurs troisièmes collaborations avec l’institution, les prêts passés se sont bien dénoués.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, des semences, des intrants, des petits matériels et payer les frais de sarclage et de labour pour entretenir 16.5  hectares.
Les productions seront vendues au niveau des marchés  de Marka-Coungo, Fana et Tingolé après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 40 000FCFA par campagne.
texts.en:
Sabougnouma 5 is composed of married women who average 29 years of age and 2 children. Most of them live in polygamous families in Djambougou, one of the villages in the rural city of Tingolé, Fana subprefecture, 2nd administrative region of Mali.

They collaborate with Kiva's partner, the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso, in order to realize their rainy season activities. They mainly grow peanuts and millet. They are seeking their third loan from Soro Yiriwaso, and the previous loans ended without problems. With this new loan, they intend to buy seeds, fertilizers, small materials, and to pay for the cost of labour and hoeing of 16.5 hectares. After the harvest, the production will be sold at the following markets : Marka-Coungo, Fana and Tingolé, to a clientele comprising both men and women.

They intend to turn an average profit of XOF 40'000 (ca US$ 85) per campaign.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizers, small materials, and to pay for the cost of labour and hoeing of 16.5 hectares

loans.name: Gloria's Group

texts.en:
T. Gloria is a hardworking and principled 30-year-old lady who, for three years, has had a merchandise shop as her business where she sells mostly home-consumption commodities. She is a married lady with three children aged 6, 3 and 18 months with only the eldest in kindergarten. She also cares for two orphans.

Previously, Gloria used to operate from Ryamatumba trading centre but now works from Bwaise in Kampala where she is able to make weekly profits of 100,000 shillings. She says that her level of cleanliness attracts more customers and she has a dream of owning a wholesale store as well as having all her children finish school. She needs a loan to be able to purchase merchandise for resale since her loans help to expand her capital base.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise for resale

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda F. is from the village of Malibangcao, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old. Erlinda is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Erlinda owns & operates a business in which she plants and harvests corn and coconut for sale. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Erlinda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Erlinda is requesting a loan of 7000 PHP to be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the first loan taken out by Erlinda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand the business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Elba

texts.en:
Elba manages a tailoring business where she sews different kinds of clothing. Her business helps her to generate enough income to be very helpful to her husband. Aside from repairing and sewing clothing she sews curtains and bed sheets, as well as school and sports uniforms. 

Because of her hard work she is able to send their children to school. However they are only at their elementary and high school level and have a long way to go. Therefore, she wants to make her business more productive. She wants to borrow PHP 5,000 from Kiva to buy more clothes and other materials needed in her tailoring business. This loan will allow her to sew more curtains and even pillowcases to sell so that she can increase her income. That will allow her and her husband to save for the future education of their children.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Sabougnouma 6 Group

texts.fr:
Sabougnouma  6 est un regroupement de femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans et  3 enfants. Elles vivent  dans des familles polygames à Djambougou  un des villages de la commune rurale de Tingolé,  sous préfecture  de Fana, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités hivernales. Les spéculations sont l’arachide et le petit mil. Elles sont à leurs troisièmes collaborations avec l’institution, les prêts passés se sont bien dénoués.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, des semences, des intrants, des petits équipements et payer les frais de labour et de sarclage pour entretenir 7 hectares.
Les productions seront vendues au niveau de Marka-Coungo, Fana et Tingolé après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 40 000FCFA par campagne.
texts.en:
The Sabougnouma 6 group is composed of married women who average 32 years of age and 3 children. They live in polygamous families in Djambougou, one of the villages in the rural city of Tingolé, Fana subprefecture, 2nd administrative region of Mali.

They collaborate with Kiva's partner, the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso, in order to realize their rainy season activities. They mainly grow peanuts and millet. They are seeking their third loan from Soro Yiriwaso, and the previous loans ended without problems. With this new loan, they intend to buy seeds, fertilizers, small materials, and to pay for the cost of labour and hoeing of 7 hectares. After the harvest, the production will be sold at the following markets : Marka-Coungo, Fana and Tingolé, to a clientele comprising both men and women.

They intend to turn an average profit of XOF 40'000 (ca US$ 85) per campaign.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizers, small materials, and to pay for the cost of labour and hoeing of 7 hectares

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita B. is from the village of Sto. Ñino, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 50 years old. Lolita is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Lolita owns & operates a sari-sari or general store where she sells food and daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Lolita has been engaged in her business for over 28 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Lolita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Lolita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Lolita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP to be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Lolita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

location.town: Sto. ñino, Tukuran Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en: Mr. M. Patrick, forty-two years old, is a businessman. He is in the motor parts business. He has a shop in town where he has been operating his business for over ten years. He is using the loan to purchase more spare motor parts in his shop to meet his customers’ demands. He has six children and his future plan is to enlarge the business and to educate the children.

loans.use: To purchase motor spare parts.

loans.name: Najobathon

texts.ru: Нажобатхон 1979 года рождения, замужем имеет 4 детей. Она не докончила школу и стала учится  на парикмахера у себя в городке.  Пять лет назад  устроилась на работу парикмахером. Через несколько лет арендовала помещение и начала свой бизнес. Сама делала прически и стрижки. Теперь ей необходимо  нанять мастера которые делает макияж. Она планирует в дальнейшем купить оборудование для визажистов и других специалистов.
texts.en:
Najobathon was born in 1979. She is married and has 4 children. She did not finish school and began studying to be a hairdresser in her town. She started working as a hairdresser five years ago. Several years later, she leased a space and started her own business. Najobathon styled and cut hair by herself. Now, she has a need to hire a specialist who can do makeup. She plans to purchase equipment for makeup artists and other specialists in the future.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Paying for specialist services

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita O. is from the village of Santa Cruz, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years old. Teresita is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns & operates a business selling fruit. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Teresita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from GDMPC. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP to be used to purchase additional inventory & towards working capital. This will be the second loan taken out by Teresita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For working capital and additional inventory.

loans.name: Leoncia

texts.en:
Leoncia A. is the mother of three. She is married to Benigno, 52 years old and a fisherman. She lives in the island village in the town of Binangonan, Rizal province in the Philippines.

As a woman of dreams, in 1995 Leoncia joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines. During the length of her membership in ASHI, she has been very active as a member, and became the leader of their center. She has been very wise in spending her previous loans.

Now on her 14th loan, Leoncia requests the amount of 45,000 pesos as additional capital for her fish pond. 29,500 pesos of her loan will be used for her fish pond while the remaining amount will be spent on her secondary businesses: direct selling and tricycle(rickshaw) transportation.

Leoncia is hopeful that she can establish a strong, sound and profitable business so that she is able to help her grandchildren with their school fees someday, and build a more durable and spacious house. She dreams also of expanding her fish pond.

loans.use: To purchase three bundles of fish nets, bamboo and other materials for her fish pond

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
“Through sacrifices and patience we are able to improve our way of living,” said Elma O., who is now 53 years old and is happily married to Erwin O.. Elma manages a little store that is commonly called a “sari-sari store”. Aside from that she sells salted eggs by going to the houses of her neighbors to further generate income. 

Elma is grateful because they are blessed with two loving children namely: Erma - 30 years old and now working abroad; and Sherwin - 22 years old who just graduated from a vocational course.

Wanting to increase the commodities available in her store, she decided to request a PHP 5,000 loan from Kiva. She is hoping that Kiva will help her to reach her dream which is to make their living better.

loans.use: To increase the commodities available in her store

loans.name: Freda

texts.en:
K. Freda is a businesswoman, forty-six years old. She has a salon and she has been operating it for over six years. She has a beautiful daughter who is schooling.

Freda is using the loan for purchasing salon items such as hair chemicals for relaxing hair, hair treatments, hair gel, hair shampoo, hair conditioners, and other hair necessities. She dreams of purchasing a piece of land and really obtaining a land title.

loans.use: To purchase salon items such as hair chemicals, gels, shampoos, etc.

loans.name: Dunstan

texts.en:
Dunstan M. is a businessman, forty-five years old. He has a retail shop in front of his house which he has been operating for five years.

M. is using the loan to purchase retail things for sale such as cooking oil, Omo (a detergent brand), wheat flour, sweets (candies), biscuits, etc., to meet his customers’ needs. He is blessed with five children, all schooling.

M. is a focused man, whose dream is to build rental houses for income generation.

loans.use: To purchase retail things for sale to meet his customers' needs

loans.name: Jalia

texts.en:
B. Jalia is a businesswoman, forty-eight years old, and she is blessed with two children; she has a retail shop near to her residence that she has been operating for three years.

B. Jalia is using the loan to purchase retail items such as drinks, that is sodas and so forth, sweets (candies), flour, cooking oil, biscuits (cookies), etc., to meet her customers’ demands. Her dream is to renovate her houses for tenants so that she can earn some money from them for survival.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as drinks, sweets, flour, cooking oil, biscuits, etc.

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva B. is from the village of Katipa. She is 32 years old. Eva is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Eva owns and operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Eva has been engaged in her business for more than four years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Eva joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eva has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets. Eva is requesting a new loan of 40000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Eva from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Prescila

texts.en:
Prescila C. is a 64-year-old woman who hails from the beautiful island village in the town of Binangonan, Rizal province, in the Philippines. She is a mother to four. Her husband, Teodoro, is 65 and her partner in business.

Before, she sold charcoal and made baskets but the business was so tedious and consumed so much time, she opted to shift her business into fishing. For her 11th loan, she proposes to borrow 40,000 pesos to purchase a motorboat for fishing. This will be their new business. 

She is hopeful that the business will grow and be sustainable since fishing is one of the staple sources of income in the island village and having a motorboat is an edge over other fishermen.

She dreams of helping her grandson with his school fees, expanding her business and building a more spacious and durable house.

loans.use: To pay for an engine for her fishing boat and other fishing gear

loans.name: Nasreen Muhammad Ashraf Group

texts.en:
Nasreen baji is the wife of M. A.. They have lived in Lahore, Pakistan, for more than 15 years. Lahore city is famous for its historical places and for Punjabi foods. Nasreen baji is a kind-hearted lady. She tries to give happiness to everyone and her members are very happy with her kind behavior. Her husband is a local master tailor and runs a tailoring center in the community. He has three years of experience in this business. Nasreen baji is applying for a loan to buy an electric sewing machine for her husband so that he is able to sew more clothes and complete orders on time. 

This group loan consists of four additional people:

Rubina baji and Safia baji each want a loan to buy materials (sugar, cooking oil and dry fruits) for their sweetmeats making and selling business.  
Farhat baji wants a loan to buy items (scissors, chairs and a mirror) for her barber shop.  
Sarwar baji wants a loan to buy sanitation supplies (pipes, taps) to resell.  

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible. 

Note: Nasreen baji is standing on the right side of the photo showing the utensils Rubina baji uses to prepare the sweetmeat.

loans.use: To buy an electric sewing machine for sewing clothes

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en:
Sorn S. is 28 years old and lives Siem Reap Province. She owns a few shops that she rents out to tourists who need to relax on their holidays. She also provides a food and soft drink service the whole day. Her husband manages their business. This couple lives with two children who are both teenagers and in school.

Sorn S. is running her business very well because her work is near the area attractive to tourists. To better meet her customers' requirements, she would like a loan from Kiva to increase her business capital in order to buy more furniture to decorate her shop and to buy soft drinks to sell.

loans.use: To buy more furniture for her shop and to buy soft drink to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To renovate her restaurant

loans.name: Parveen Muhammad Rafiq Group

texts.en:
Parveen baji has been a citizen of a city named Lahore, Pakistan for the past 15 years. She is an uneducated lady because her parents couldn’t send her to school due to a lack of financial resources. She is married to M. R., who has a business selling garments. He sells both ladies and gents garments in the market. He has been in this business for over four years. He buys garments from the city of Multan because the clothes prices are very cheap there, and he earns good profit on the clothes. Parveen baji is requesting a loan to advance her husband’s business.

This loan consists of four additional people:

Hafizan bajfi and Sajida baji each want a loan to buy material (beads, colored thread and clothes) for their decorative embroidery business. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Rehana baji wants a loan to buy cooking oil, sugar and dried fruits for her sweetmeat-making business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: Parveen baji is standing in the first left side and showing Shahnaz baji's refregerator in which she keeps cold drinks and juices for selling.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Abida Parveen Altaf Hussain Group

texts.en:
Abida parveen baji is a wife of A. H. and has lived in a city named Lahore, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Lahore is famous for its historical places and for Punjabi foods. Her husband runs a business selling medicines. He buys medicines wholesale and sells them to medical stores to earn income. He has been in this business for the past five years. Abida baji is applying for a loan to advance his business.

This loan is consists of four additional people:

Zubaida baji wants a loan to buy a lathe machine. Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy seasonal vegetables to sell. Mairaj baji wants a loan to buy clothes to sell. Saeeda baji wants a loan to buy paint boxes to sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: Abida baji is seated on the front left side in this photo.

loans.use: To buy medicines to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Mubashira Nadeem Zahid Group

texts.en:
Mubashira baji, wife of N. Z., has lived in the city of Lahore, Pakistan, for the past eighteen years. Lahore city is famous for its historical places and for its Punjabi foods.

Mubashira baji is a very active lady and runs a food-selling business. She prepares food items such as potato cutlet and vegetable rolls and sells them in the community. Her food items are very popular with people. She does this work to pay off the utilities of her house.

Mubashira baji’s husband runs a beauty salon in the community and has been in this business for the past five years. His salon is famous for its variety of haircuts and hairstyles. Mubashira baji is applying for a loan to buy items (scissors, creams and hair gels) for her husband’s beauty salon.

In the photo, Mubashira baji is standing in the middle of the group showing her food items.

This loan also consists of two additional people: 
 
Nusrat baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits to sell.

Anwar baji wants a loan to buy rice to sell.

loans.use: To buy materials for her husband's beauty salon

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida D. C. is the mother of four and lives in Morong, Rizal, in the Philippines. She is 66 years old and married to 61-year-old Juanito and they are blessed with four children. Some of her children have their own families already.

In 1999, Leonida joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, full of dreams to overcome poverty. With her previous loans, she used those in a variety of businesses but, years later, she ventured into the resale of yearly calendars and ready-to-wear clothes. She has been doing this for several years already.

Now on her 9th loan, Leonida is requesting 45,000 pesos as additional capital for the resale of calendars and ready-to-wear clothes. 38,000 of her loan will be used for the resale of calendars while 7,560 (including additional capital) will be used for the resale of ready-to-wear clothes.

Leonida is hopeful that she can establish strong businesses so that she can help her grandchildren with their school fees and can invest her money in assets such as the procurement of land and other things.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her calendar and ready-to-wear clothes businesses

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy Ceńir is a woman with the courage and determination to get out from the spiral of poverty. She is 38 years old and the mother of five. Her husband, Delfin, is 39 years old and a fisherman. They reside in the island village in the town of Binagonan, Rizal, in the Philippines.

With her determination to rise-up from poverty, in 1995 Mercy decided to join ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines. During her previous loans, she was noted for being wise in spending her loans. Now on her 11th loan, she requests a loan of 40,000 pesos to pay for fishing gear and a fishing boat which she finds to be a helpful and very productive business.

Mercy is positive that her business will grow and can give her enough proceeds to sustain the school fees of her children. She also dreams of having a fish pond (a place to grow fish) someday.

loans.use: To pay for fishing gear and a fishing boat

loans.name: Maqbool Muhammad Sharif Group

texts.en:
Maqbool baji is a wife of M. S.. They have both been citizens of Lahore, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Lahore is famous for its Punjabi food and its historical places. M. has sold leather for the past 4 years. Currently, Maqbool baji is requesting a loan to advance her husband’s business.

Maqbool baji is the leader of a loan group that includes four other women.

Ruqaiya baji wants a loan to buy construction supplies (sand, brick and cement) to sell.
Munawar baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.
Khursheed baji wants a loan to buy seasonal vegetables to sell.
Khalida baji wants a loan to buy material (minced meat, cooking oil and spices) for her food selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible for doing so.

Note: Maqbool baji is seated in the second right side of the bajis. The photo also shows members of Khursheed baji's business.

loans.use: To buy leather to sell

loans.name: Princess

texts.en:
Princess R. is only 19 years old, yet she is strong and determined to find a way to raise herself up from poverty. She lives with her partner, Rommel, who is a 29-year-old fisherman. They plan to get married soon. Together, they have one child.

She joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 2008. Since she has an 11-month-old baby and is still taking care of it, she proposes a loan of 10,000 pesos to pay for the stock and groceries that she will be selling in her sari-sari store (general store). The store will surely be the center of the neighbors’ eyes since they can buy most basic needs/groceries in it.

She is optimistic that in the near future she can convert her store into a grocery store and be able to save for her child’s education.

loans.use: Additional capital for sari-sari store (general store)

loans.name: Aileen

texts.en:
Aileen A. is a 22-year-old woman with hopes for a greener life. She lives with her (soon to get married) partner Jonar, a 25-year-old fisherman. Aileen hails from the beautiful island town of Binangonan, Rizal province, in the Philippines.

She joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 2008. Since her partner is a fisherman, Aileen is requesting a loan of 10,000 Philippine pesos (or about $225) to pay for three bundles of fish nets and 20 pieces of bamboo to make fishing gear.

Aileen is hopeful that, with the industriousness of her partner, she can make their fishing business grow and fulfill their dream of having a fishing boat someday.

loans.use: To pay for 3 bundles of fish nets, 20 pieces of bamboo, and other materials to make fishing gear.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel K. has a small boutique and sells shoes and other ladies clothing at Gabi in Kpando. Samuel has received a senior high education.  Samuel has been operating the boutique since 2002. He is responsible for his utility bills and other financial expenses. His loan will be used to buy more of the clothing to sell. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to invest in a different lucrative business.

loans.use: To buy more clothing to sell.

loans.name: Wisdom

texts.en:
Wisdom D. is a fitter and an auto mechanic who repairs cars and sells spare parts at Konda in Kpando. Wisdom did not receive any form of formal education. He is married and has two children. His wife is a petty trader who earns little for a living.

Wisdom has been in the fitter and auto mechanic professions since 1990. He is responsible for the paying of school fees and other financial responsibilities in his home. His loan will be used to buy more spare parts to sell. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to build a house.

loans.use: To buy more spare parts to sell

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana M. is 51 years old and a mother of two. Both of her children have already graduated from high school and are planning to go college if they have enough money to pay for the university fees. She is married to Jaime a 55-year-old pier porter (one who carries the baggages of passengers). They live in the island-village of Malacaban, a town of Binangonan, in the Rizal Province of the Philippines.
Juliana joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines in 2005 and was able to receive loans from them to invest wisely on her business. Now on her fourth loan, she is proposing the amount of 20,000 PHP to pay for the materials needed for her primary business, the crafting of fish cages (for small fish ponds).
Juliana is hopeful that the business will run smoothly with the help of her husband and children. She even dreams of extending it and being able to send her children to college since they stopped schooling after high school.

loans.use: To pay for the materials needed to make fish cages

loans.name: Jemima

texts.en:
Jemima T. has four dependents. She has received schooling through junior high. She uses her income solely for her personal needs and those of her dependents.

Jemima is a food vendor who sells banku (corn dough served with hot pepper or soup) and rice recipes in Kpando, which she has done since 2005. Jemima will use the loan to purchase more of the ingredients for the banku she sells. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to reinvest into her business.

loans.use: To purchase more ingredient for her banku

loans.name: Evans

texts.en: Evans A. is a single parent who has two children. He has received schooling through senior high education. Evans sells electronics items such as slightly used irons, TVs, car batteries and cassette recorders in Kpando, which he has done since 2007. Evans uses his income for housekeeping expenses.  With the high demand for Evans' gadgets, he will use the loan to purchase to more of the slightly used electrical gadgets to sell. With the new profits from his expanded business, Evans plans to reinvest into the business.

loans.use: To more inventory

loans.name: Algaa

texts.en: Algaa B. is 27 years old and currently lives with her husband and two daughters in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her oldest daughter is seven years old and a high school student. The youngest daughter is just one year old and her parents take care of her. Algaa sells various food products at the local food market. She rents a small stall at the market and sells food products, including soft drinks, crackers, candies, etc. She has been in the food retail business for the last nine years and has gained significant experience at the local market. Her husband always helps her pick food products from the local wholesale markets. Since the start of her small business in 2000, her business has been expanding; her business capital has increased more than tenfold from 250,000 MNT to 3,000,000 MNT. She says that she dreams of making her small business into a secure and stable business in the future.  She requests a loan to purchase more food products for her business.

loans.use: To purchase food products

loans.name: Bernice

texts.en: Bernice B. is married and has two children. She has received schooling through tertiary education. Bernice sells a variety of assorted provisions in Central market, Kpando, which she has done since 1999. Her husband is a trader. Bernice uses her income for payment of the children's school fees and all the financial needs of the children. Bernice will use the loan to purchase more provisions to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Bernice plans to reinvest in the business.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria D. is a married mother of two children. She has not received any formal education. Victoria has earned her living as a food vendor of fufu, banku, and cooked rice in Tsakpe New Town since 2000. Fufu is a local Ghanaian dish that is prepared from cooked cassava and plantain that is ground, pounded and mixed together, then eaten with soup. Victoria uses her income to pay for her children's school fees and other financial needs. Victoria will use the loan to purchase more fresh food stuffs and cook more to meet the demand of her clients, and use the new profits from her expanded business to reinvest into the business.

loans.use: To purchase more food items to meet the demand of her clients.

loans.name: Meriam

texts.en: Meriam A. is a 45-year-old single woman. She is persevering and striving hard for a better life.  She lives with her father in the beautiful island village of Kinabaogan in Binangonan town, which is located in Rizal province in the Philippines. In 2008 she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, and is now requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP to use as additional capital for her retail business of beauty products, clothes, slippers, shoes, underwear, and many other ready-to-wear products.  She dreams of earning a good profit so that she can save for her father's medical needs and to help pay the school fees for her nephews.  Also she will make some repairs to their house.  She hopes that someday her business will grow and expand to offer delivery to nearby places.

loans.use: As additional capital for retail of beauty products, and other ready-to-wear products.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice A. is a vendor of rice and kenkey in Tsakpe New Town. Kenkey is a local Ghanaian dish prepared from fermented corn dough which is cooked and wrapped in corn husk and eaten with hot pepper. Beatrice has received a junior high education and is a single mother of two children. Beatrice has being a food vendor since 2003. She is responsible for paying the school fees for her children. She will use the loan to buy maize in large quantities to cook kenkey for selling. She hopes to reinvest the new profit back into her business.

loans.use: To buy maize in large quantities for cooking and selling kenkey.

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary B. is married and has eight dependents. She has received schooling through junior high. Her husband is a driver who lives on a small income.

Rosemary is a food vendor and sells non-alcoholic beverages in Kpando, which she has done since 2007. She uses her income solely for the financial expenses of her large family. She will use the loan to purchase more of the non-alcoholic drinks to expand her restaurant.

With the new profits from her expanded business, Rosemary plans to reinvest in the business.

loans.use: To purchase more of the non-alcoholic drinks to expand her restaurant

loans.name: Odmaa

texts.en:
Odmaa O. is 30 years old and lives with her husband and 2-year-old daughter in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her daughter goes to a local kindergarten when her parents are away for work.

Odmaa sells women’s and men’s clothes at the local blackmarket. She rents a small stall at the market and sells the clothes that she brings from Ereen, China. Ereen is a border town where many local small vendors visit and purchase cheap yet trendy Chinese apparel for women and men. Since the start of her small business in 2006, her business has expanded and her working capital has increased fivefold from 100,000 MNT to 500,000 MNT ($1 USD = 1,450 MNT).

In the future, Odmaa hopes to expand her business as capital allows and intends to increase the variety of clothes that she brings from Ereen, China. She requests a loan to purchase more clothes from Ereen for her small business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes from Ereen, China

loans.name: Peace

texts.en:
Peace D. is a food vendor who cooks rice recipes and sells them in Kpando Central Market. Peace has received senior high education. She is single and has four dependents.

Peace has been cooking and selling since 2003. She is responsible solely for her personal needs and those of her dependents and for other housekeeping expenses. Her loan will be used to buy a variety of fresh foods which she will cook and sell. She hopes to reinvest the new profit in her business.

loans.use: To buy a variety of fresh foods to cook and sell

loans.name: Bernice

texts.en:
Bernice A. is a young entrepreneur who did not receive any formal education. Bernice sells kenkey and fried fish at the old taxi rank in Kpando, which she has done since 2000. Kenkey is a Ghanaian dish which is prepared from fermented corn dough that is cooked and wrapped in the corn husk and eaten with hot pepper.

Bernice uses her income to pay for her water and electricity utility bills. She will use the loan to purchase maize and fresh fish to fry and sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Bernice plans to invest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase maize and fresh fish to fry and sell

loans.name: Oyun

texts.en:
Oyun J. is a single mother with three children. She lives with her three sons in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her oldest son is 25 years old and works as an engineer for a local mining company. The next son drives a cab in the town. Her youngest son is 18 years old and goes to a local high school.

Oyun plants various vegetables on a small plot of land she owns and sells those vegetables once they are harvested. She has been in the business for the last six years. She started her vegetable-growing business with small capital of 100,000 MNT ($1 USD = 1,450 MNT) in 2003 and her working capital currently ranges between 1,000,000 MNT to 4,000,000 MNT depending on the harvest season. She has just recently started small-scale bee farming.

In the future, Oyun would like to continue to expand both her vegetable-growing and bee-farming businesses on her own. She says that she is very optimistic and excited about her businesses. She requests a loan to purchase more bees and vegetable seeds for her businesses.

loans.use: To purchase more bees and vegetable seeds for her businesses

loans.name: Kobildjon

texts.en:
Kobildjon is a 22-year-old married father of two children. His wife is a housekeeper and she supports him in everything he does. He is a hardworking young man and he has been providing taxi services for four years. The most important thing to him is that his children attend and successfully finish school so they can be professionals and have a better tomorrow. Kobildjon wishes to keep his taxi business growing, and for this he needs to keep his tools in good working order. He needs to buy spare parts to improve their condition and that is why he is requesting a loan. Thanks to this career Kobildjon has been able to stabilize his quality of life.    

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its epic mountain passes and its rich history which includes its place as a key post along the Silk Road and events at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has produced famous thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged an already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural productivity and the manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.


IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent viable business prospects. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase parts needed to repair his tools and taxi.

loans.name: Shurentsetseg

texts.en: Shurentsetseg Y. is 38 years old and lives with her husband and two teenage children in Arhangai Province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her two sons are both high school students. Shurentsetseg sells meat in small pieces at the local food market. She has been renting a small stall at the local market and selling mostly mutton and beef to locals for the past ten years. She started the meat business in early 1999 with small capital of 300,000 MNT. Since then, she has gained significant experience and has regularly visiting local customers. Her business capital is currently exceeding 2,500,000 MNT (8 times more than the starting capital). Her husband always helps in her business. He drives his small truck to nearby herder families and purchases cattle and sheep for the business. She requests a loan to purchase more meat for her business and plans to use the profit to get a full repair for her husband's truck.

loans.use: To purchase meat for her business.

loans.name: Doris

texts.en: Doris D. sells different kind of cosmetics, ranging from body lotions and creams, in Hohoe central market. Doris has received schooling through junior high. She is a single mother of one child. Doris has been selling cosmetics since 1996. Her loan will be used to buy more cosmetics to sell. She hopes to reinvest the new profits back into her business.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics to sell.

loans.name: Abdou

texts.fr: ABDOU D. est un membre de la mutuelle depuis un an ;il est marié et vit avec sa famille au quartier cité senghor de thies;il était chauffeur de camion en cote d'ivoire depuis plusieurs années .depuis son retour à thiès ,il a ouvert une cantine ou il vend des pièces détachées,il travaille avec son neveu qui est en europe;avec ce pret,il veut renforcer son commerce
texts.en:
Abdou D. has been a member of the credit union for one year. He is married and lives with his family in the Cité Senghor neighborhood of Thies. He was a truck driver in Cote d'Ivoire for several years. Since his return to Thies, he has opened up a little shop where he sells spare parts. He works with his nephew who is in Europe. With this loan, he wants to bolster his business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: selling spare parts

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en: Mabel O. is married and has three children. She has received schooling through junior high. Mabel is a distributor of a variety of cooking oils in Hohoe central market, which she has done since 1999. Mabel will use the loan to purchase cooking oil in large quantity to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mabel plans to invest back into her business.

loans.use: To purchase cooking oil in large quantity

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine A. sells earrings, panties and mother care products in Hohoe central market. Christine has received a junior high education.  She is married and has three children. Her loan will be used to buy more of the mother care products to sell. She hopes to reinvest the new profits.

..."mother care" in Ghana offers ongoing support for newborns and mothers...

loans.use: Buy more mother care products to sell.

loans.name: Genevieve

texts.en: Genevieve A. sells cosmetics, clothing and jewelry in Hohoe's central market. Genevieve has received a junior high education.  She is married and has four dependents. Genevieve has been selling cosmetics and jewels since 2000. Her loan will be used to buy more cosmetics, clothing and jewelry at wholesale and at retail. She hopes to invest back the new profit from her business.

loans.use: Buy cosmetics, clothing and jewelry to sell

loans.name: Christine

texts.en: Christine K. is a young lady who was educated through Basic school. Christine sells salt, onions and a variety of spices for cooking in Hohoe's central market. She uses her income to supply her personal needs for which she is solely responsible. Because her spices are in high demand, Christine will use the loan to increase her inventory and variety of spices to sell.  With the new profits from her expanded business, Christine plans to make investments back into the business.

loans.use: To purchase more spices.

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana M. is a young entrepreneur who received schooling through basic education. Christiana sells salt, onions and selected spices for seasoning in the Hohoe central market, which she has done since 2004. Christiana uses her income solely for all her financial and personal needs. Christiana will use the loan to buy more of the spices and sell in larger quantities. Christiana plans to reinvest the new profits from her expanded business.

loans.use: To buy more spices.

loans.name: Ndi

texts.en:
Born on the 16th of April in 1982, E. is single with two children below the age of fifteen. She lives at Mile 90 Nsongwa Mezam Division, Bamenda, Cameroon. She is a very hard-working young lady. Though she did not make it through school, she is still determined to succeed in life and to provide for her children what her parents could not do for her. Given her fourth loan, she plans to invest in opening a restaurant. More specifically, she will buy foodstuffs like beans, corn and vegetables to cook and sell. Experience has taught her how to manage a business like this one. Her business site is located in a very good area. Food-selling is in high demand in the locality where she stays.

E. loves GHAPE because of the low interest and the social interactions among members. These interactions bolster her loan utilization and management.   

 The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Purchase black and red beans, groundnuts, fertilizer, manure

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca A. sells goods like panties, clothing and cosmetics at Elmina. Rebecca has received a senior high school education. She is married and has seven dependents. Her husband is a captain in a boat.

Rebecca has been selling goods like panties and cosmetics since 2006. She is responsible for paying the school fees of her children and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy to buy more panties, clothing and cosmetics for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to to build a house and to save the rest.

loans.use: To buy more panties, clothing and cosmetics for sale

loans.name: Millicent

texts.en:
Millicent A. is a hairdresser who owns a beauty salon and who also sells weavons (hair extensions), mesh and clothes at Teterim which is near Elmina. She has received junior high school education. She is married and has one child.

Millicent has been selling weavons, mesh, and clothes since 2007. She is responsible for paying the electricity bill. Her loan will be used to increase her capital so that she can buy more weavons, mesh and clothes to sell at the market. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest into the business and to save the rest.

loans.use: To buy more weavons, mesh, other hairdressing products and clothes to sell

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua T. is divorced and has three dependents. She has received schooling through junior high school.

Ekua sells smoked and salted fish. She goes to the shore to buy fresh fish from the fishermen and then sends the fish home. She processes them by salting some and smoking the rest before she sells them at the market at Elmina, which she has been doing since 1999. Ekua uses her income to pay the children’s school fees and the electricity bill.

Ekua will use the loan to purchase more fresh fish to process for sale at the market. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to build a house and to save the rest.

loans.use: To purchase more fresh fish to process for sale at the market

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy A. lives in Elmina where she sells bathroom slippers. She has received senior high school education. She is widow and she has three dependents.

Mercy has been selling bathroom slippers since 2007. She is responsible for paying her children’s school fees and also the utility bills at home. She will use the loan to increase her capital to buy more slippers for sale. She then intends to use the profits she gets to buy a machine for her boat and to save the rest.

loans.use: To increase her capital so as to buy more slippers to sell

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah E. sells firewood and provisions at Elmina. She has received a junior high school education. She is married and has two dependents. Her husband is a trader.

Hannah has been selling firewood and provisions like milk, sugar, Milo (a milk beverage) and so on since 1999. She is responsible for paying utility bills and also supports her husband in educating their children. Her loan will be used to buy more firewood and the groceries she trades in, to sell at the market. She hopes to use the profits she gains from her business to reinvest into her trade and then to save the rest.

loans.use: To buy more firewood and provisions to sell at the market

loans.name: Kwesi

texts.en:
Kwesi M. sells goods like paint and bowls which he does at Elmina. He attained an education at the senior high school level. He is married with eight children. His wife is a fishmonger.

Kwesi started his business this year. He is responsible for paying school fees and utility bills at home. His loan will be used to increase his capital to purchase more bowls and paint for sale. He hopes to use the profits he gains from his business to build a house and then to save the rest.

loans.use: To increase his capital to purchase more bowls and paint for sale

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis A. is a trader and has two children. He has received schooling through to the senior high school level.

Francis sells goods like rice and parazone (either a bleach or a herbicide) at Elmina. He has been in this trade since 2006. Francis uses his income to pay the utility bills at home. He will use the loan given him to buy more bags of rice and parazone for sale. With the new profits from his expanded business, he plans to build a house and to save the rest.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice and parazone for sale

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua N. is divorced and has four dependents. She has received schooling through senior high school. Ekua is responsible for paying her children’s fees and the electricity bill. Her husband is not employed.

Ekua sells foodstuffs like tomatoes, beans, yam and so on, which she does at Elmina Market. She has been doing this since 1995. She intends using the loan to buy more foodstuffs to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to further her children’s education.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Kwadwo

texts.en: Kwadwo A. is married and has eight children. He has received schooling through senior high school. Kwadwo sells wood at Yanta near Elmina. He started this business in the year 2004. His wife is a teacher. Kwadwo is responsible for paying school fees and utility bills. Kwadwo will use the loan to purchase more wood for sale. With the new profits from his expanded business, Kwadwo will then build a new house and save the rest.

loans.use: To purchase more wood for sale.

loans.name: Mangwi

texts.en:
Mangwi G. was born in 1966 and is the mother of one child. G. originally joined GHAPE and got her first empowerment credit in 2008 and since that time, she and her husband have enjoyed the benefit of GHAPE empowerment credits. With her first loan, she invested in farming and has used the profits of her products to invest in her child and family, paying for her brothers' and sisters' school fees and for their medications.
Throughout the years, G. has suffered the consequences of poor health, and the death of her husband. Besides that, G. and her family have simply suffered the results of poverty and the accompanying challenges that life has brought them.
 She has years of experience in her business, which has helped her in having sound business policies. 
With her second GHAPE loan, she intends to invest in expanding her business. With the profits of this business, she will be able to afford the school fees of her other children, and will be able to continue providing good healthful medications for them. She will be able to feed her family, provide them with clothes and will have the opportunity to save for the future as well. 
G. came to GHAPE because of the training scheme the organization offers, because of the terms of the loans, and because the method of repayment is “comfortable and convenient”.
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase yams, corn, and beans

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua E., who received junior high school education, has been selling tilapia and maize at Elmina since 1999.    She is married to a Mason and they have six dependents. Ekua is responsible for paying the school fees of her children as well as the utility bills. She is requesting the loan to buy more tilapia and maize for sale at the market and hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a house.

loans.use: To buy more tilapia and maize for sale at the market.

loans.name: Chi

texts.en:
Born in 1946, S. is the father of five children. He has been a very hard-working man from childhood since he was unable to further his education due to poverty. Life has been very challenging for S., especially due to the fact that thieves have always made life very difficult for him.

When S. finally gathered the pieces of his life back together again, he decided to start afresh. He learned about GHAPE and became a member in 2005 and has already received and repaid two loans from the organization, finding it easier to support his family as a result. S. loves GHAPE because of the training and social activities of the organization.

For his third loan, S. plans to continue cultivating crops such as beans, coco and yams and rearing pigs. In addition to processing cassava, he will also continue rearing fowls. Profit from his business will then be used to pay school fees for his children, medical bills and for feeding and clothing himself and the five children.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Purchase of seeds, fowls, chemicals, and feed.

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent N. is a tailor in Rwamagana, Rwanda. At 27 years old, he is married and is the father of two children.

Vincent has requested a loan of 500,000 Rwandan francs (FRW). He and another client, Chantal Uwingabire, share a shop together and are looking to expand their business by purchasing an electric sewing machine. The beautiful foot-powered sewing machines they currently use at the shop will withstand the frequent electricity shortages, but are unable to create the classic "zig-zag" stitch of quality, modern clothing. With the new machine, he expects to be able to increase business, working faster and creating better quality garments.

With the profits from the loan, Vincent hopes to pay school fees for his children and start some personal savings. This is Vincent's first loan with Vision Finance Company.

loans.use: To buy an electric sewing machine

loans.name: Tebui

texts.en: R. is married with four children and is finding it very difficult to meet the needs of her children all by herself. Her greatest wish is to give her children a very good education and she therefore has to work very hard to make this wish a reality. R. has been a seamstress for a very long time but, because of limited capital, has not been producing on a scale large enough to yield enough to meet her family’s needs. Motivated by other GHAPE members in her community, she decided to join the program in 2007 and she received her first loan of 20,000 FCFA in that year which she invested in buying cloth and sewing materials. Given this new loan, R. plans to add the money to what she already has established, and plans to buy cloth, thread, and also pigs to raise and seeds to plant. As she has been in her seamstress business for a very long time, she is confident that her problem has just been that of inadequate capital. The profit R. gets from the loan will be used to pay for her children’s education and to improve the standard of living within her home. Her community stands to benefit from her activities as she will boost the supply of designed clothes in the market. R. prefers a loan from GHAPE because there is no collateral security involved. About GHAPE The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profit and loss, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase cloth, thread, and also pigs to raise and seeds to plant

loans.name: Chantal

texts.en:
Chantal U. is a dressmaker in Rwamagana, Rwanda. She is married and is the mother of five children with one other child dependent.

Chantal has requested a loan of 500,000 Rwandan francs (FRW). Chantal and another client, Vincent Ndatimana, share a shop together. Chantal is looking to purchase an electric sewing machine. The beautiful foot-powered sewing machines they currently use at the shop will withstand the frequent electricity shortages, but are unable to create the classic "zig-zag" stitch of quality, modern clothing. With the new machine, she expects to be able to increase business, working faster and creating better quality garments. In fact, Chantal would like to get more into the bridal-wear industry!

With the profits from the loan, Chantal hopes to pay school fees for her children, afford more food for them, and start some personal savings. This is Chantal's first loan with Vision Finance Company.

loans.use: To buy an electric sewing machine

loans.name: Eveline

texts.en: M. was born in 1974 and is happily married with four children with two of them below 15 years of age, and all going to school. Being a very hardworking lady, she has faced some major challenges in life such as being a school dropout and having an inferiority complex because of a poor education standard. But she has gone on struggling to meet up with life against all these challenges. By so doing, she came to know of GHAPE in which she became a member in 2008, obtained a loan of 40,000 FRS, and repaid it successfully. Given her new loan, M. plans to buy rice, waterfufu (cassava dough), beans, vegetables, oil and seeds for farming. The loan repayment will start from the day of disbursement. She is sure the business will succeed because of the training being given to her by GHAPE. Furthermore she has been doing the business for a long period of time. Notwithstanding, she has a ready market for her goods and she is quite sure the business will succeed. Her community will benefit from her activity by having food at their disposal, reducing their distance to the market in order to get what she is selling. Due to the progress of the business, M. plans to use the profit from the business to pay for her children’s school fees, to expand the business and to feed the family. She prefers loans from GHAPE because GHAPE is trustworthy, the method of repayment is convenient, and GHAPE usually educates before giving out the loan. About GHAPE The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profit and loss, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy rice, waterfufu, beans, vegetables, oil and seeds for farming

loans.name: Peragia's Group

texts.en:
N. Peragia, 50 years old, is a hard working and determined widow. She cares for her 5 children who are all in school and she also cares for 2 dependants. 

Peragia has sold produce in Rushaka Trading Centre for over 10 years. She sells produce from her farm and buys produce from farmers in the villages using her loans to avoid shortages. The secret behind her success is the commitment and loyalty she has toward those she serves and works with.

She is now in a position to make a profit of 400,000 shillings per month. She requests a loan to be able to buy more produce for resale.  

Peragia says that although the father of her children is long gone, she has managed to have a happy family amidst all odds and this gives her fulfillment in life.

loans.use: To buy more farm produce for resale.

loans.name: El Señor Es Mi Pastor Group

texts.en:
Marcia lives in Barrio Azul Andres, Boca Chica, a municipality that belongs to the Santo Domingo province. In Barrio Azul Andres everyone knows each other and there is a strong sense of family. 

Marcia used to work at a "Banca," a small gambling and lotto hot spot. She is no longer employed but needs income to keep her household running, especially because she has two young kids. Her kids are photographed above -- as you can see, the boy is 6 years old and her daughter is 10 months old.

This is Marcia's first loan with Esperanza. With the money she will start her own boutique from home. She plans on buying clothes primarily for women, shoes, and purses to resell in her community. She plans on promoting her business by putting signs outsiD. her home and by telling her community that she has a new business. 

Marcia hopes that her business can take off so her kids can benefit from the profits.

Don't hesitate to support Marcia and help her group become successful entrepreneurs in their community. Thank you.

loans.use: To buy jeans, dress shirts, shoes, and women's bags to resell to local communities.

loans.name: Alioune Badara

texts.fr: ALIOUNE BADARA M. est un enseignant de profession;il fait du commerce de produits divers pour améliorer ses revenus ;il loge au quartier grand thies avec ses parents;avec le crédit qu'il sollicite ,il veut renforcer son fonds de roulement
texts.en:
Alioune Badara M. is a trained teacher. He sells various products to add to his income. He lives in the Grand Thies neighborhood with his parents. With the loan that he is requesting, he wants to bolster his working capital.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: adding to his working capital

loans.name: Juma

texts.en:
Juma N. lives in the small coastal town of Shanzu, just north of Mombasa.  He is a 41 year old married father of four. He owns a workshop that he has been working in for the last 12 years. Juma also owns a passenger service motorbike and sells clothes to supplement his workshop income.

This will be his first loan from KADET and he is very excited about it.  With the 30,000 Kenyan shilling loan, Juma plans to purchase timber, service his carpentry tools, and increase his clothes stock.

In the future he hopes to fully furnish his workshop with various machines through subsequent loans from KADET, in order to satisfy and win more orders from his many clients.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To purchase timber, service carpentry machines, and to buy clothes to resell.

loans.name: Delfina

texts.es: Delfina tiene 40 años, es una mujer muy responsable con su trabajo, vive con el padre de sus 2 hijos en su casa propia. Anteriormente sólo se dedicaba a la siembra de papa y arveja, pero desde hace 2 años empezó también a sembrar flores (gladiolos), por ser muy rentables durante las festividades. Para ello, alquiló chacras donde siembra los meses de enero y julio, para cosechar en las fechas claves, llegando a vender cada paquete de 12 docenas en 70 u 80 soles, pasadas estas fechas baja el precio hasta 20 soles por paquete. Entonces en esas épocas se dedica a sus cultivos de papa y arveja hasta el mes de octubre, donde nuevamente suben los precios de las flores. Aunque a veces debido a la sequía demoran en reventar los capullos, trata de contrarrestar este problema regando por las noches para facilitar el florecimiento de sus chacras. Delfina se siente muy contenta en la siembra y venta de flores y para que las trasporte sin maltratarse hasta el mercado, las envuelve cuidadosamente con papeles y rafia que guarda para la ocasión. Este es su décimo crédito con MFP y en todos estos ciclos demostró puntualidad en cada uno de sus pagos. Asimismo viene cumpliendo con mucha responsabilidad su cargo de tesorera de su banco comunal, donde se ha ganado el aprecio y respeto de todos sus compañeros. El dinero que solicita lo piensa utilizar en la compra de fertilizantes químicos para sus siembras de flores, para que coseche en el mes de octubre.
texts.en:
Delfina is 40 years old, a very responsable woman who lives with the father of her 2 children in her own house. Before she used to sew potato and pea, but 2 years ago she also started sewing flowers (gladiolus) which are very profitable during the holidays. Therefore she rented land where she sews in the months of January and July in order to harvest on the key dates, thus being able to sell each packet of 12 dozen for 70 or 80 soles. After these dates the price is 20 soles per packet. During the low seasons she sews potato and pea until the month of October where the price of the flowers raise again. Sometimes the draught delays the flowers but then she waters them at night to facilitate the flowering on her land. Delfina is very happy sewing and selling flowers and in order to transport them safely to the market she wraps them carefully with paper and raffia which she keeps for the occasion. This is her tenth loan with MFP and she has always made the repayments punctually. She also carries out her post as treasurer of her community bank with responsibility and has earned the esteem and respect of her partners. The money will be spent on buying chemical fertilizers for the flowres so she can harvest in the month of October.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Elsa

texts.es: Elsa
texts.en: Elsa

loans.use: Purchase raw material and beverages.

loans.name: Estela

texts.es: Estela acaba D. cumplir 60 años, es una mujer muy atenta y D. buen trato, está felizmente casada y tiene 2 hijos adultos. En su juventud pudo construir dos casas, en una vive con su esposo y la otra se le cedió a su hijo para que viva con su familia. Debido al arduo trabajo que tuvo en su juventud ahora sufre dolencias en sus pies, pero eso no la desanima a seguir trabajando en sus chacras y pese a sus limitaciones apoya a su esposo en el cuidado D. sus plantas. A ella le gusta mucho contemplar sus siembras y trabajar en ellas, para ello se levanta a las 5 D. la mañana para cortar los leños y preparar los alimentos; luego a las 8 D. la mañana enrumba hacia su chacra, donD. su esposo ya está desarrollando los trabajos agrícolas y ella alegremente se suma al trabajo. Durante todos estos años la agricultura les ha dado muchas alegrías y gracias a ella pudieron construir sus casas y brindarles comodidades a sus hijos. Por ello, esta pareja no piensa dejar sus siembras, D. lo contrario mientras les queden fuerzas siguen adquiriendo más terrenos para alquilarlos en sus años D. vejez. Estela viene trabajando durante 10 créditos consecutivos con MFP, durante estos años demostró puntualidad en los pagos y está muy acostumbrada con todos los integrantes D. su banco comunal a quienes les tiene mucho aprecio, como D. familia. El dinero que ahora solicita lo piensa invertir en la compra D. 10 sacos D. fertilizantes químicos, calcula que le costarán 1900 soles, con el resto pagará el trabajo D. los peones que limpiaron y prepararon su chacra para la siembra.
texts.en:
Estela just turned 60. She is a thoughtful woman who treats others well. She is happily married, and she has two adult children. In her youth she was able to build two houses.
