In 2009, Rodellia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rodellia is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which she will use to purchase the ingredients for the foods that she sells. This will be Rodellia's first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase the raw ingredients needed to make products to sell

loans.name: Aurora

texts.en:
Aurora C. hails from the island village of Kinagatan in the town of Binangonan, Rizal province, in the Philippines. She is 47 years old and married to Eduardo, who is a fisherman and also a farmer. She is the mother of three. She is full of determination and has discipline within her for things that can fight poverty.

She joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 1997 and was given the opportunity to have access to capital. She invested her previous loans in her sari-sari store (general store) and wisely managed the business. Now on her eighth loan, she is requesting the amount of 19,000 pesos to pay for purchases for her store: 10 sacks of rice, one gallon of gasoline (resale), two sacks of brown sugar, one sack of white sugar, liquors, and groceries.

She is positive that her business will grow bigger with the help of her husband and children. She dreams of sending her children to school up to college and to have savings for their personal needs in case of emergencies.

loans.use: 10 sacks of rice, three sacks of sugar, liquors and other groceries for her general store

loans.name: Iraneo

texts.en:
“We must be patient in order to succeed,” says Iraneo, a motor tricycle driver in the village of Bonfal Proper in Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. He is married to Myrna and blessed with loving children. He hopes that his children will finish their studies and be employed in good jobs.  

Iraneo wants to repair his motorcycle to have a smoother transporting business and for his passengers to be safe. For this reason, he seeks a loan from Kiva of PHP 6,000 for motorcycle maintenance and to buy some necessary motorcycle accessories. His wife, on the other hand, is working as domestic helper abroad. They help each other earn income for the future of their children.

loans.use: Motorcycle maintenance

loans.name: Sreng

texts.en:
The two people in the picture are K. N. and her husband. They live in Kompong Cham Province. K. N. is a local crop farmer, growing rice, vegetables and some fruit on her own farmland. To help meet the family's daily expenses, her husband works driving a motor taxi. K. N. has four kids, one of whom is working in the garment industry. 

K. N.'s husband has been using the existing motor taxi for a long time; their motor is now too old and often breaks down. Therefore, K. N. is applying for a loan to replace the old one.

loans.use: To replace an old motor

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
“I want to make my life productive, so I make the best out of it,” Erlinda L. shared. At 52, Erlinda is still craving a good life, not only for her, but most importantly for her family. At present she owns a general store, which is situated at their house at Buenavista, Santiago City, Isabela. Aside from that she is also engaged in hog raising. In spite of her age, she really doesn't feel exhausted managing a store and, at the same time, cleaning the animal pen with the bad smell of animal manure. With her and husband’s hard work, they are able to support their family's needs.

However, Erlinda wants to further expand her business, thus she decided to seek a loan amounting to PHP5,000 from Kiva lenders. She knows that she will become successful in her plan because her family is always there to support her. Their care and love is her motivation to strive in every step that she makes. Furthermore, she hopes that Kiva lenders will help her achieve her dream.

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Charito

texts.en:
Charito H. is 42 years old, married with 3 children and is a resident of Brgy. Ma-ao, Bago City, Negros Occidental, Philippines.

She needs additional capital to increase her purchasing capacity so that with more fish to sell, she can expand her business and increase her profits and ultimately save enough money for the education of her children.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has owned and operated a fish vending business for the past 3 years.

loans.use: Additional Capital for her fish vending business

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fish vending is the source of income of Mrs. Fe B. of Buenavista, Santiago City, Isabela. She buys fish, specifically milkfish, in the market and sells them in their village. With this business she is able to earn PHP 500 a week and this income is just enough to support their daily food requirement. Thus, she is really working hard for her business to grow for the future of their children.

Fe wishes to borrow PHP 5,000 from Kiva to have additional capital. She can use the loan for buying more milkfish or other kinds of fish so that her customers will have other choices. Through this, she is hoping that her income will increase so that her children can go back to school again for they were forced to quit before because of her financial problems.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen, the 39-year-old wife of Norlando O. Jr., lives in the village of Buenavista Santiago City where she serves as a dealer of beauty products and different types of RTW’s in order to help her husband satisfy their daily needs. She is hoping that her business will become more productive and more profitable to improve their way of life. As well, she wants to meet the needs of her customers and so is requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 from Kiva to buy additional products that her customers might require.

“I am very optimistic that through the loan my business will progress, and of course when that happens, a better living for my family will follow,” Helen proudly says.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Business-minded - that best describes Mrs. Janeth O.. She is a Tupperware vendor in their village but, aside from that, she also sells beauty products. She also manages a fish pond as another source of income. With her businesses, she is able to generate income for her family. Most of her earnings are being used for their daily expenses, thus she is somewhat worried because her three children are already attending school.

Wanting to secure the future of her children, Janeth is being motivated to borrow from Kiva the amount of PHP 5,000 for use as additional capital. With that, she will somehow feel she can relax because she can save money for the education of her children. Moreover, she believes that with her perseverance and hard work, she will become successful and eventually her determination will bear fruit.

loans.use: To use as business capital

loans.name: Morm

texts.en: Mrs. Morm C., 44 years old, lives with her family in the rural area of Kompong Cham Province, Cambodia. She and her husband have been local crop farmers for over nine years, selling their mature produce every two months to earn profit. Morm C. will be using this Kiva loan to grow a rice crop during the approaching farming season. They have six children who are still young and under their care.

loans.use: To grow a rice crop during this approaching farming season.

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
“I know that education is the worthiest thing that I can give to my children. There is a better future ahead of them if they have college diplomas,” Melanie says. She really values education and so is doing her best to earn money to support both their education and their daily needs. Melanie knows that sending children to school is costly because of daily allowances, tuition fees and projects.

Melanie’s main source of income is through her general store, located at their house in barangay Buenavista, Santiago City, Isabela. In order to secure her children’s future, she wants to further develop her business so as to generate a higher income. To attain that goal, Melanie is requesting a loan from Kiva amounting to PHP 5,000 which she can use as her additional capital. She knows that Kiva lenders are kind-hearted; thus she hopes that her request will be granted.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel V. is from the village of Kinuman Norte, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 30 years old. Maribel is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Maribel owns & operates a sari-sari or general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Maribel has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Maribel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maribel is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Maribel from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit  offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en: For 10 years now, Perlita R. has been supporting her family through her sari-sari store. According to her, maintaining a sari-sari store that long is such an achievement. However, in those ten years only a little improvement took place. Thus, she decided to avail a loan from Kiva amounting to PHP5,000 for her additional capital. She is very positive that through her loan, her business will progress. She also says that her loan will be used for purchasing other products for her store, so her customers will have more choices.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Kang

texts.en: Kang K. A., 31, lives in Kompong Cham province, Cambodia. She has owned a plot of land since 1999. She grows both rice and vegetable crops. She cA. plant her crops twice a year, the dry season and the rainy season. She requests a loA. for capital to expend on growing a rice crop. She is married to Doung Toung, 39, who assists her in the farm actions. The couple is responsible for two children. Both of them are single and in school. (Kang K. A. and her husband are pictured).

loans.use: To expend on growing a rice crop

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita A. is one of the best performing members of ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines since 1995, from the time she joined the institution. She is 58 years old and mother to six children. She is strong in facing trials of life even though she is widowed already. She lives in the island village-Malacaban, Binangonan, Rizal province.
She uses her capital wisely and really invested it in a profitable business. Before, they were making chairs sets made of bamboos. Now they shifted their business into a fish cage (fishpond) where they cultivate fish fries (fingerlings) until they are ready to be harvested and sold in the market. For her loan, she proposes an amount of 25,000 pesos to pay for 20,000 pesos worth of fishnets and 5,000 pesos worth of fish fries (fingerlings) as her primary business.
They been doing the business for more than a year already and they want to invest more in it. She is positive that with the help of her children, they can make their business grow and it could give them back enough proceeds for their family needs. To help her grandchildren with their school fees is also one of her top dreams.

loans.use: To purchase fish nets and fingerlings

loans.name: Ronaldo

texts.en:
Ronaldo L. is a bread vendor at Buenavista, Santiago City, Isabela. Every morning he roams their village to sell his bread using his motorcycle. Wanting to improve his business and eventually have his own bakeshop, Rolando is really working hard everyday. He says that even though sometimes he feels tired, he still continues to sell for the future of his two children. Because of this, he wants to borrow PHP4,000 from Kiva lenders to purchase more bread that he can sell every morning.

His wife, Yvett, on the other hand, is working as a call center agent in Manila. Though his wife is not staying with them because of her work, he always sees to it that they have communication. Rolando also shares that he and his wife are willing to sacrifice for the benefit of their children.

loans.use: To purchase more bread to sell

loans.name: Sally

texts.en:
“There is money from junk,” Sally proudly says. She is engaged in a business buying and selling junk material. With her tri-bike she roams around their village to buy empty cans, bottles (glass, plastic), galvanized iron, etc. After buying from their village she then sells the articles in the junk shop at Santiago City.

Sally is already 39 years old and married to Noel who helps her in her business. Wanting to increase her income, Sally decided to request a PHP 5,000 loan from Kiva for her to buy more junk material to increase her income. She and her husband are saving for the education of their children, thus she really hopes that Kiva will lend her the money.

loans.use: To buy more junk to sell

loans.name: Chham

texts.en: S. H. is a 46-year-old farmer and mother of six children. Five of her children are single, while one is married and lives away from home. To help feed the family, two of her daughters are garment workers in Phnom Penh, while her husband sells a few products for a profit. To earn additional income, S. H. is requesting a loan on Kiva as capital to purchase arecas, beans, and sesames from rural farmers. She will sell them to market sellers at a profit. She and her husband are pictured at their house.

loans.use: To purchase arecas, beans, and sesames from rural farmers

loans.name: Bernadith

texts.en:
Bernadith R. is from the village of Kinuman Norte, Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental. She is a 42-year-old married mother of three school-aged children. To make a living, Bernadith owns and operates a business in the retail sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and daily use products in the local community through her store. Bernadith has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Bernadith joined Kiva partner, GDMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bernadith is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About GDMPC
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Letecia A. is 44 years old and a mother of two, a boy and a girl. She is married to Eustaquio, a fisherman, and lives on the island village of Malacaban, Bainangonan, Rizal province. Letecia is a woman of faith and determination to rise above poverty.

In 1995, Letecia joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, and was noted for her exemplary performance. When she joined ASHI and was able to have access to capital, she invested her loan in the resale of fish. But years later, she opted to set up a fish cage (fishpond) business, which she found more profitable and easier to maintain. Currently, she has fish caging as her primary business and the resale of fish as her secondary business.

Now on her 11th loan, Letecia is requesting the amount of 45,000 PHP to pay for the materials needed for her fish cage business: 3 cages worth 30,000 PHP, 100 pieces of bamboo worth 5,000 PHP, and 10,000 PHP worth of fingerlings. Letecia is optimistic that her business will grow bigger and will bring enough profit for her family's needs. She is also hopeful that with the proceeds from her business, she can send her youngest daughter to college to finish her desired course.

loans.use: To buy fish cages, pieces of bamboos and fingerlings

loans.name: Otgon

texts.en:
Otgon S. lives with his wife and three small children in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. His oldest daughter is 14 years old and goes to a local school. The next daughter is just 6 years old and goes to a local kindergarten. His son is just 1 month old and stays with his mother at home.

Otgon has a small retail business in clothing. He started his clothing business in 2006 with capital of 150,000 MNT ($1 USD = 1,450 MNT). He frequently travels to Ereen, China, a border town from where many Chinese cheap products are imported, and buys cheap yet trendy clothes for women and men.

Since the start, Otgon has done well and his business capital has increased to 2,500,000 MNT. With the profit, he was able to purchase a small car for his family’s needs. In the future, he would like to expand his business by selling more diverse clothes for women and men. He requests a loan to purchase more clothes from Ereen, China.

loans.use: To purchase more men's and women's apparel

loans.name: Irene

texts.en: Irene O. is from Kinuman Village, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. Irene owns and operates a specialized retail store, primarily selling bananas in the local community. Irene has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 6,500 PHP a month. In 2009, Irene joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Chhin

texts.en:
Chhin C. N. is an older woman living in the province of Kompong Cham, Cambodia. She is married with two children, all of whom are married and have already started new homes. Her husband helps be responsible for the family by driving a horse-and-cart taxi.

Chhin C. N. plants various crops to earn a living. Due to this coming farming season, the heavy rains are still falling. She is looking for a loan from Kiva’s partner HKL and will use this money to grow rice and vegetable crops.

loans.use: To grow rice and vegetable crops

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is 38 years old and he is living in Barangay Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. Due to difficulties in his life, Richard was not able to pursue his college education and ended up finishing at high school level. He is still single and he dreams of having a successful life someday for his family. He wisely uses his time to earn a living by operating a tricycle transport business in their village.

Through his business, he is able to support his parents and sustain their daily needs at home and also with the education of his younger siblings. Aside from his tricycle, he is also hoping to have a little store to be managed by his mother so that they have another source of income. In this regard, he is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP 12,000 that he will use for the maintenance of his tricycle and, hopefully, to start a village store. He believes that someday his business will grow through the continuous support of the lenders.

loans.use: To use for the maintenance of his tricycle and, hopefully, to start a village store

loans.name: Romel

texts.en:
“To gain success, be patient and strive for the best,” said Romel. He is married Jacquelyn and they are happily living in Barangay Bonfal Proper in Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. They have three children: the eldest is disabled while the other two are presently studying in the elementary school located in their village. Romel said he will do his best in order to give his children a bright future.

Romel works as a tricycle driver. But aside from this, he and his wife are also delivering coconuts to their customers in their village using their tricycle. Sometimes he also works as a part-time furniture maker.

At present, Romel would like to obtain a loan of PHP 10,000 in order to develop their fresh coconut (buko) delivery and to maintain their motorcycle’s needs. According to him, they will work hard to make their business progressive.

loans.use: To develop their fresh coconut delivery business and to maintain their motorcycle

loans.name: Tsend-Ayush

texts.en:
Tsend-Ayush D. Is 61 years old and lives with her husband in the Baganuur district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She just finished repaying her first loan with Kiva and is now requesting a second loan!

Her three children are all grown-up and live with their own families. Her husband has leg problems and cannot walk without assistance. Besides taking care of her husband, she runs a small fast food store where she serves various local dishes, including steamed and fried dumplings. She mostly serves to locals who work and visit the local black market. She is quite well-known for her delicious food at the market.

She says that she enjoys cooking meals for those who are working hard in the market to make their living. She further notes that she gains lots of energy and respect from locals’ appreciation of her delicious meals. At her food store, she also trains those kids who would like to learn how to cook but have no money for training fees. 

She requests a loan to purchase more meat for her food business.

loans.use: To purchase more meat for her food business

loans.name: Janice

texts.en: Janice A. is from the village of Kinuman Norte, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 26 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. Janice owns and operates a food stall, selling vegetables in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Janice joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Svay

texts.en: The two persons shown in the picture above are Svay S. and her husband, at their house. Svay S. earns a living growing different kinds of crops on her farmland in the village, while her husband who owns a cultivating machine rents it out to farmers for daily income. This couple has six teenage children: five are students and one works in the casino club and provides a salary to meet the family’s demand. Recently, the family’s daily income has been decreasing due to the fact that their cultivating machine often has broken. Therefore, Svay S. has decided to seek a loan to repair the existing machine.

loans.use: To repair a cultivating machine

loans.name: Leslie

texts.en:
Leslie V. is from the village of Kinuman Norte, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old. Leslie is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Leslie owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector, running a sari-sari, or general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Leslie has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Leslie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leslie is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Leslie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Khun

texts.en: Khun P. is a modest person of twenty-five years, who lives with her family in Siem Reap province. She is married with two kids who are minors and a school-aged child. She helps be responsible for her family by selling a few fresh fish in the local market, through which she can make around $2 of profit a day. She is married to Bunthoeun, 38, who owns a car to provide a taxi service for income. Recently, Khun P.’s husband isn't earning as much money as before because his taxi is not attractive to the customer. Khun P. hopes to decorate the taxi by using the Kiva loan to pay for painting the taxi.

loans.use: To pay for painting the taxi

loans.name: Dymphna

texts.en:
Dymphna A. is a 39 year old woman and a mother of two children namely Cazandra Mae and Cheyz June. Dymphna has been a member of ASHI for nine years and her loans from this institution have been very helpful to her and her family. The most significant change she realized about herself when she joined ASHI is her more positive attitude towards other people and perception towards circumstances she is having. Because of the opportunity of loaning she had with ASHI, she developed her self-esteem and she was able to manage her own business.

Residing in a village near the sea, the livelihood of most people is fishing. Dymphna started her buy fish vending business when she first loaned in ASHI while her husband drives a rented motorcycle with sidecar (popularly known as "tricycle"),  which is the main means of transportation of people in the whole municipality. Dymphna is striving hard to grow her business in order to save some of her earnings to buy a tricycle for her husband. In this way, they will earn bigger because her husband doesn't need to pay for the rental of the tricycle and this can also be used as her means to sell her fish directly to people in different villages.

Dymphna's was able to achieve her dream partially when she received her previous loan. She bought a motorcycle yet she still needs to buy a sidecar for a tricycle. This is the reason why Dymphna applied for another loan after her previous one was paid. Some of the amount of her loan will also be used in buying fish to sell.

Once Dymphna achieved her dream for her business, there will be no doubt that she will also achieve her dreams for her children. Cazandra is on her second year in high school while Cheyz is in his Grade 6 in elementary grade. Soon, Dymphna will be having college students and she hoped that she can sustain her children's education. Her loans from ASHI for her business would be a great help for her in achieving those dreams.

loans.use: Purchase of sidecar for motorcycle, and fish to sell.

loans.name: Marlene

texts.en:
Marlene P. is a 40-year old married woman. She has five children and unfortunately, the twin babies inside her womb were aborted just recently for reasons she don't know. It was a indeed a heartbreak for Marlene and her husband, Jimmy, because they did not know that the six month fetus inside her womb were twins. Because of poverty and no enough nutritious food taken, she might have not given them proper nurture. However, Marlene had to move on with her life and her dreams for her other five children. She recently applied for a loan in ASHI amounting to PhP 48,000 in order to purchase a motorcycle in installment basis having a downpayment of Php20,000 and sidecar in cash payment of Php30,000 for her tricycle (motorcycle with sidecar attached to it) for her husband to drive. 

Tricycle is one of the main means of transportation of people coming in and out of the village all throughout the municipality. Marlene's husband has been driving a tricycle for hire owned by other people for 20 years now. This is Marlene's daily source of income since her farming business which was her primary business since the beginning of her membership in ASHI, can only generate income every four months. With the increasing need of her family finances her husband and their farming business can hardly sustain, they have to increase their income. Having their own tricycle to be driven by her husband, the whole of his daily earnings will go to the family because he doesn't have to pay for the tricycle rental. 

Having been a very good member of ASHI in the past nine years, showing a very good performance in payment, attendance and business, there would be no doubt that Marlene will be able to do better with her present loan applied. Her dreams of giving her children better education and better life motivates her to move on and make good in her business.

loans.use: a motorcycle and sidecar (to be attached to the motorcycle).

loans.name: To

texts.en:
To V. is 34-year-old married woman. She is the mother of four school-age children. 

To V. and her husband are fish catchers; they have used their life on the river because the reason of fish. They can fish around 10 kilos of fish a day and sell them out to buyers in bulk, at about $1.50 per kilo. 

Recently To V. and her husband can't catch as much fish as before because their tool is often broken. Thus, To V. has decided to ask for a loan to buy more fishing tools. She hopes the new tools will help her family to catch more fish than previously.

loans.use: To buy extra fishing tools.

loans.name: Belinda

texts.en:
Belinda Q. is from the village of Santa Cruz, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental. She is 30 years old. Belinda is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Belinda owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising pigs. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Belinda is just starting this business.

In 2009, Belinda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Belinda is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will used to purchase pig feed and other supply. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Belinda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase pig feed and other supplies

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Note: Seng R. was not available for photographing, so her husband is shown in the picture instead.

Seng R., 50, sells fishes that she gets from her husband's fishing. She also buys fish in bulk from other fishermen and brings them to sell at the market.

She is a good mother blessed with five children; four of them are single and one is married and has started a new family home.

Seng R. will use her loan to purchase additional equipment for her husband to use for fishing. Her loan will help the family accrue their income and better manage their daily finances.

loans.use: To purchase additional equipment for her husband to use in fishing.

loans.name: Rohat

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 

Рохат женщина 50 лет, замужем имеет двоих детей.Живёт вместе с семьёй сына.Её муж работает бригадиром в строительной бригаде.Сын водитель городского маршрутного такси. Сама Рохат нигде не работает, домохозяйка, но занимается откормом скота. А продаёт её муж и сын, т.к. продажа скота это считается мужской работой.Рохат для увеличения численности скота решила получить в Арванде кредит . Сейчас у неё две большие коровы, которые дают молоко. Прибыль полученную в дальнейшем хочет потратить на ремонт дома.
texts.en:
Rohat is 50 years old, married, and has two children. She lives with together with her family and her son's family. Her husband works in construction as a foreman. Her son is a mini-bus driver in the city. Rohat herself is a housewife, but she feeds the cattle. And her husband and son sell the cattle, as selling of cattle is considered men's work. Rohat, in order to increase the number of cattle, decided to take out a loan from Arvand. Now, she has two big cows which give milk. With the income that she makes, she hopes to spend on home repairs.

Translated from Russian by Josh Machleder, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: feed and sale of cattle

loans.name: Mansu

texts.en:
Mansu S. is a resident of Sainbu-Bhaishipati. Sainbu-Bhaishipati is located in Lalitpur district and most of the people in this region are engaged in agriculture.

Mrs. S. lives in a single family with her husband, Mr. Utam S., and two sons. Her husband went to foreign country to work. Her older son is studying in grade 5 and younger son is studying in grade 4.

Mrs. S. opened a small food shop three years ago to improve the economic condition of her family. She sells a variety of food items in her shop, including Nepali food such as dalbhat (rice). She also serves tea and coffee to the customers. The demand for food in her town is increasing. Therefore, Mrs. S. is requesting a loan of 15000 NPR to buy ingredients to produce more food.

loans.use: To buy food materials for her work.

loans.name: Dinara's Group

texts.en:
M. Dinara is this group’s leader. She teaches English in a local school and at the same time holds the position of Vice Principal. She has three children: two sons, both of whom work, and one daughter, who is a school student.

About a year ago Dinara started her own business of cattle raising. She bought two calves and now these calves have gained weight and in fall she is going to have them sold or slaughtered for meat. She wants to expand her business and needs a loan to build a new yard for her cattle as the one she has at the moment is in a bad condition. This yard is not suitable for her cattle in wintertime and therefore she is taking precautionary measures now, so that she does not lose her cattle in winter.

She says that having a business apart from a regular job helps her be constantly active and motivated. 

The other members of the group include Mairamkul, Gulyasyl, Kachkyn and Gulmira.

Mairamkul is a married woman aged 51. She owns a small shop and besides that makes national carpets. She needs a loan to rebuild her yard for her cattle and to increase its area.

Gulyasyl is a housewife. Many years ago her family bought some cattle and since then she has raised it and now she sells her cow’s milk. All of her children have their own families, but she prefers to live independent of her children.

Kachkyn is the mother of four children and works in construction. At the same time she manages to breed cattle for which she has ten-years of experience. She has a pretty decent income and now needs a loan to purchase some more cows.

Gulmira also works at a construction site in the capital. She used to work as a masseuse. Then she bought some calves and started cattle raising. She wants to purchase some more calves to raise them for her son’s wedding and then to resell the rest. 

As can be seen, all the members of this group combine two or more jobs and that makes them even more passionate about their plans.


======================================
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit:  www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at  www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To build a new yard for her cattle

loans.name: Milicent

texts.en: Milicent is a 26-year-old entrepreneur. She is a married mother of two children who go to school. The family lives in Likoni, Mombasa. Milicent runs a beauty shop which she initiated in 2007. She supplements this with the sale of clothing materials and ladies' handbags. She gets her products locally and, at times, travels to Kampala, Uganda, for more varieties. Milicent is requesting her loan to help her get more supplies.

loans.use: Get more supplies

loans.name: Genese

texts.en:
Genese D. is from the village of San Vicente, Tambulig, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 39 years old. Genese is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Genese owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising ducks. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising ducks for sale. Genese is just starting this business.

In 2008, Genese joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Genese has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase ducklings to raise & sell in future. Genese is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase feed & other supplies for the ducks. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Genese from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family and tuition of her children. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Nasipa's Group

texts.en:
Nasipa is the leader of this group. She works in the security service of “Kyrgyz Railroad”. She is forty-seven and has three children. Apart from her daily work she is occupied with cattle breeding. And recently she has been reconstructing her yard to be able to keep more cattle.

Nasipa needs a loan to purchase sheep and gradually increase their number. She has found that, in wintertime, selling meat is quite a profitable activity, since more people tend to buy meat at that time. 

Nasipa’s partners are Gulnura, Munara and Venera. 

Gulnura is thirty, married, and has two children. She needs a loan to purchase seeds and hay for their sheep, because at this moment the hay cost is relatively low.

Munara is forty-three, married, and has three children. She works in “Al – suu”, a limited liability corporation. She makes the labels. She needs a loan to purchase a bale of cotton for making traditional seat-carpets. Then with the rest of the money she wants to buy a sheep. Now she wants to help her son finish his college education and, besides that, she is planning her daughter’s wedding and now is making some preparations for it.

Venera is forty-five, married, and has four children. She also works as a label maker in “Al – Suu”. Now, Venera needs a loan for irrigation of her land and cultivation work. After doing that, she is going to grow clover and maize. 

“We cannot wait until somebody comes and gives us the opportunity to create our businesses; we shall better strive to create opportunities for ourselves,” say the members of this group.


======================================
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit:  www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at  www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase sheep

loans.name: Va

texts.en:
Va N. is a fish seller, aged 33, and is a married mother caring for two kids who are pupils in the local public school. Her husband also works with her in selling fishes. This couple usually wake up in the early morning in order to buy fish in bulk from fishermen and hurry to bring their fish to the local busy market to sell them. They typically make around $7 of profit each day to manage their own family, especially to make sure their kids can attain the highest of education.

In the past, the family has always hired a taxi as transportation for their business operations. Right now, they want to reduce taxi costs by using a loan to buy a motorbike, which they will use to transport fish to sell.

Note: Va N.'s husband is pictured above.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Kumondor's Group

texts.en:
Kumondor, the group’s leader has raised four children. She is disabled (has one kidney) and obtains a pension. Nevertheless, not used to depend on someone, she earns her living by sewing bags and packages and sells them wholesale or to her individual customers. A friend of hers inspired Kumondor to start this business and, during five years, she has gained great experience and knowledge. She amused her family with the profits and now even one of her sons and her husband help her by cutting and packing the material. She started her business with only one sewing machine and gradually bought several other models.

Kumondor’s daughter is getting married and Kumondor needs a loan to help her with the wedding. Another of her future plans is to help her son get married. Kumondor is an example of a rare parent, who in spite of their age (49), and health problems, in a self-sacrificing way continues to support their family, helping their children financially.

Gulnara, Gulzat and Aigul are the rest of the group’s members.

Gulnara is forty-four and is the mother of six children. She sews bags and distributes them among her friends in a market. Now she needs a loan to purchase new models of sewing machine and to get one broken one mended.

Gulzat, 39, is married and is raising four children, all of whom go to school. She teaches Kyrgyz language and literature at a local school. Inspired by her neighbors’ success she wants to obtain a loan to start her own business of raising cattle.

Aigul, a married woman of forty-four is the mother of three children. She brings bull-calves, horses and sheep from Naryn and pastures them to resell them in a cattle market. She needs a loan to increase her turnover and make some renovations at home.


======================================
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit:  www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at  www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To pay for her daughter's wedding

loans.name: Natividad

texts.en:
Natividad H., 48, a separated mother of two, runs a store with her married daughter where she sells charcoal, firewood and mineral water. She also cooks and sells pancit (a noodle dish) and rice cakes for snacks. Every weekend, she buys dressed chicken in bulk and sells it to her neighbors. Natividad earns P15,300 monthly.

Natividad has applied for a loan to buy sacks of rice and other merchandise for her store.  With additional income, she prays that she will be able to renovate her house.

loans.use: sacks of rice

loans.name: Kuku's Group

texts.en: This group’s leader, Kuku, has five children and one of her daughters still goes to college. Her neighbor sells bags at a market. She gave Kuku some bags and Kuku sold them. Afterwards she started her own business. Her husband works as a bus driver on the Bishkek – Tokmok route. He purchases packages and thread for her and brings them home. Kuku needs a loan to purchase chickens. She has already prepared a roost for them. She is planning to increase their number and in future sell eggs, hens and chickens. After saving enough money she wants to raise horses since it is more profitable. Her dream is to travel all around Europe and Asia with her husband. Kanymkul, Aigul and Maratbek are Kuku’s loan partners. Kanymkul is forty seven. Every day she turns in five liters of milk for five soms per litre and also sews items of traditional clothing. She needs a loan to purchase some chickens in order to sell eggs. With the money earned she wants to prepare her daughter for the new academic year. Aigul is married and has three children. She sells milk and runs her own shop next to her house. She needs a loan to buy a new fridge for selling meat and chickens. In future she plans to buy ten cows and build a big back-court. Maratbek is married and is the father of five children. He works as a shepherd in the village and looks after his farm. He needs a loan to purchase chickens and, with the money earned, he wants to buy new school clothes for his kids. He says: “Even though I am an ordinary country man, I want to give my children a good education so that they live totally different lives from mine.” ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase chickens

loans.name: Joseline's Group

texts.en:
N. Joseline is a hard-working and principled mother, divorced with 5 children aged 16 – 6 years, in primary and secondary schools. Joseline has a general merchandise shop where she sells mostly home-use and home-consumption commodities in Butatare trading centre in Bushenyi. It is a big market area and she is able to make a weekly profit of 100,000/=. She has a business experience of 6 years and her good customer care has kept her business intact.

Joseline has a hope of opening up another shop in Mbarara to grow her business as well as seeing all her children educated up to university level. This is her 4th loan with the group and she needs this loan to help purchase more merchandise for sale in her shop since all her loans have been helping in increasing her capital.

loans.use: Buying more merchandise for her shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy more supplies for re-sale

loans.name: Frevisminda

texts.en:
Frevisminda O. is from the village of Poblacion, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 47 years old. Frevisminda is separated from spouse and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Frevisminda owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising pigs. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Frevisminda is just starting this business.

In 2009, Frevisminda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Frevisminda is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed & other supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Frevisminda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living condition of the borrower's business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental.Its membership composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase pig  feed & other supplies

loans.name: Juvy Ann

texts.en:
Juvy Ann B., 27,  is married mother of two boys. Her husband, Godofredo, is a government employee.

Juvy has run a variety store in a destitute area of Buntong Palay, San Mateo, Rizal for more than two years.  Her store caters to the basic needs of their community, including rice, purified drinking water, and electronic load distribution (mobile phone credit). Before a recent break-in, her store earned a weekly profit of P5000. The thief who broke into her store ran off with grocery items and  all the money in her cash box. With little inventory, and no money to replace the stolen items, she is only earning around P2,000 a week now. Her new loan will be used to replenish her store and to buy sacks of rice and purified drinking water in five liter containers. She also wants to start up a "lutong ulam" (cooked food) business for added income. Juvy considers this bad experience as a wake up call from God because her store kept her very busy, even on Sundays. It was almost two years ago when she last attended a Sunday Service. With renewed mind and spirit, Juvy knows that God will bless her business again.

loans.use: Sacks of rice, purified drinking water, and grocery items

loans.name: Phy

texts.en:
Mr. Phy S., 24, is a good father caring for a lovely young child. He and his wife currently earn their daily income by selling fresh fish in Psa Tmeiy Market located in Siem Reap Province. This young couple retails fish that they buy in bulk from their wholesale suppliers who are fisherman who fish in Tunle Sap River. They have been running this business for over nine years and earning an average of US$ 5 profit per day.

Approaching fishing season, the fish is commanding the lowest price. Therefore, Phy S. requested a loan for capital to order various type of fish at the cheapest price, which he can sell at higher prices.

loans.use: To order various types of fish

loans.name: Ndefru

texts.en:
G. is married with four children. She lives in Ntamulung quarter in Bamenda, Cameroon. G. and her entire family are living in a house with 5 rooms with three people sharing a room. Being a very hard-working woman, G. had to overcome some challenges in life. Thieves broke into her business site some time in 2008 and also broke into her house. They took a lot of things which almost let to her downfall. Being a hard-working woman she was able to overcome this problem.

With this loan, G. plans to buy firewood ( a fuel used locally in cooking). She will also buy flour, yeast, and vegetable oil for frying cakes. Some of the vegetable oil will be used in frying plantain chip (sliced plantain fried in vegetable oil). She will also buy chickens to grow for sale and feed for the chickens. Part of the money will also be used for transportation of the items from the market to her business site.

This will be G.'s fourth loan from GHAPE; she has been a member since 2005. She has been quite successful in the past with her business due to her location (right on the main road), the quality of her products, and her reasonable prices. Also with experience, she now has more customers who consume her products.

Part of her profits from this loan will be used to buy a plot of land for building a house. She will also use some to pay her children's school fees, and provide food and medication for the family. G. does not foresee a problem with her loan repayments as they are quite small repayments every month. She intends to start repayment in the fourth month after taking the loan.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Buying firewood, chickens, frying cakes and plantain chips

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma D. is from the village of Water Fall, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 36 years old. Vilma is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Vilma owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a sari-sari or general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both beverage and daily use products in the local community. Vilma has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2000, Vilma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Vilma is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Vilma from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family and to pay the tuition fee of the borrower's children.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Water Fall, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Lang

texts.en: The man shown in the picture is Mr. Lang K., 21, a fisherman. He usually needs to take eight hours a day to fish,  in and around Tunle Sap River. He catches around 10 kilos of fish per day and sells them in bulk to his customers who are retail sellers in the market. His wife’s name is Sinath; she is 19 and works with him in the fishing business. The young couple is blessed with one young child who is still not enrolled in school. Lang K. will use his loan to purchase nets, traps, and other fishing implements so he can catch more fish.

loans.use: To purchase nets, traps, and other fishing implements

loans.name: Elizabeth Jepwambok

texts.en:
Elizabeth is forty-seven years old, married, and a mother of three.  She operates two "posho" mills; one is in Kapsoya and another one is in Illuah, both neighborhoods within Eldoret.  Posho mills grind staple grains such as corn and wheat.

Elizabeth has been operating this business for the last fifteen years and from the profit she gets from her business, she has managed to educate her three children, and feed and clothe her family.  She has serviced four other loans from KADET and hopes with this fifth loan she will be able to repair and service her posho mills and offer better services to her customers who are also within Eldoret.

In future, Elizabeth hopes to diversify her business, buy a plot of land, and build residential houses for rental purposes. She also intends to educate her children to Master's degree level.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within these communities.

loans.use: To repair and service "posho" mills

loans.name: Janet Nelima

texts.en:
Janet Nelima is a fifty-one-year-old dairy farmer in Muzenywe center in Kakamega town. She is married with six children. Janet owns one dairy cow and  will use this loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to purchase one more dairy cow.

Her existing cow's milk production has greatly declined and she believes that with another cow, her milk production will increase, thus boosting her monthly income.  With her dairy business, she has managed to look after her family successfully.


About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To purchase one dairy cow

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en: Angelita is 48 years old and married to Cayetano.  They have four children, and three of them are already married.  Angelita hopes that she can access a loan amounting PHP 5,000 for the improvement of her vegetable vending business.  Managing her business gave her the opportunity to help her husband in uplifting their status of living. She wants her children to grow with a progressive and comfortable living.  She said that “with patience and unity, life can be meaningful and successful”.

loans.use: Business Improvement

loans.name: Bernadeth

texts.en:
Bernadeth M. is a young mother residing in Barangay Sinili, Santiago City. She is engaged in charcoal and vegetable vending as her way of assisting her husband in providing for the needs of their family. She is married to Marlon, a tricycle driver who also works as a farmer. They have two children and all they want is to give them a better life. Through their hard work and patience, they believe that they will succeed in life. Their two children are Reymark - 2 years old and Rachelle - 2 months old.

Bernadeth would like to access a loan amounting to PHP 4,000 for the improvement of her vending business. This amount will be of great help in fulfilling her plans for her business.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha is a vendor of fruits and vegetables in their village. She is already 52 years old and still very diligent in the business. She purchases her products from her neighbors who have their own vegetable farms and banana crops, then sells them at retail prices.

At present, she would like to borrow PHP 5,000 that she will use to increase her merchandise. Her business is really important to her because it is their main source of income. Though her three children are already married, Editha still sometimes extends help to them, especially when it comes to her grandchildren.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Leddy

texts.en:
Leddy is 35 years old and married to Larry. She operates a village store and at the same time manages her hog-raising business. She is requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 in order to have additional capital for her business. She is positive that this amount will certainly provide her with an increase in income that she will use to further support the education of her children.

Leddy is also hoping for her business to grow and be productive through the support of the lenders. She further said that “strong determination to succeed will somehow give positive results of whatever someone longs for.”

loans.use: To use as business capital

loans.name: Celestina

texts.en:
Celestina A., 62, is a widow with a grown daughter (who is also a businesswoman).

Celestina owns and manages a togue (mung bean sprouts) and lumpia (spring roll) wrapper making business in Concepcion Dos, Marikina City. The business was started by her husband 20 years ago and has been the family's sole source of income ever since. Celestina and her four employees (one of whom is shown in the picture with Celestina) deliver their products to nearby markets in Commonwealth, Parang, Tumana, and San Mateo as early as 2 o'clock in the morning. The businesses consumes four bags of mung bean sprouts (totaling 100 kilos) and 50 kilos of flour every day. Celestina earns a daily net income of 1500 to 2000 Philippine pesos (or about $30 to $40 US dollars). The loan she's requesting will be used to buy more mung bean sprouts and flour because her family's present capital is no longer enough to supply her growing business.

Celestina dreams that through this business, she will be able to buy the house and lot she is now renting.

loans.use: Mung bean and flour

loans.name: Alice Lum

texts.en:
Alice is married with six children. She lives in Azire, Cameroon.  Alice and her entire family live in a house with 4 rooms.  Alice overcomes many challenges in life such as taking care of her children and supporting her husband by paying fees for their children. 

Alice runs a restaurant business frying gateaux (a kind of cake) in front of the family compound with the support of her children. She plans to invest this loan in her business and other farm work. Alice hopes expand this business since she has been operating it for a number of years.

This will be Alice's second loan from GHAPE. She has been a member since 2008.  Her business is very successful due to its location and Alice's reasonable prices.  Thanks to the experience she has, she now serves more customers.
 
Part of her profits from this loan will be used to take care of her ageing mother, as well as to buy necessities for her family and her grandchildren. The other part of the loan will be used to improve her farm. Alice intends to start repayment immediately on the day of collection.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: The improvement of her gateaux-frying business and her farm.

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en: Hog raising is the chosen business of Leticia.  It has enabled her to send her children to school. She is 34 years old and has a husband named Philip.  Leticia aims to make her business grow so she can help fulfill the needs of her family. However, lack of capital hinders her.  Because of this, she is requesting a loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos (or about $125 US) from Kiva lenders so she can maintain her hog raising business. Leticia says that executing her profession with passion and interest will help her develop her business.

loans.use: To help maintain and develop her hog raising business.

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita is 51 years old and married to Juanito, who operates a motorcycle as the primary means of family livelihood. The motorcycle requires important maintenance for the safety of Juanito's customers, so Merlita has requested a loan amounting to PHP 4,000.

To supplement the income from her husband's tricycle operation, Merlita sells charcoal in their village.

She and her husband are blessed with seven children, five of whom are married. Judith, 22 years old, is single and a student, and Joe Mae, 11 years old, is still in school.

Merlita hopes that her loan will be granted for the sake of the welfare of her family.

loans.use: Maintenance of the motorcycle that serves as the family's primary business

loans.name: Prescila

texts.en:
Prescila operates a sari-sari store business (a sar-sari is a community-based general store). Sometimes she also sells vegetables for additional income. She aims to become a successful businesswoman someday, which is why she is doing her best to maintain her enterprise. Prescila asking Kiva to to support her by granting her loan request of PHP 5,000.

Prescila is 39 years old. She is married to Elmer Sr. and they are blessed with four children: Elmer Jr., 18 years old and a high school graduate; Merbin, 16 years old, and an elementary school graduate; Elsie, 13 years old, in her second year of high school; and Erika, eight years old and in the second grade.

Prescila hopes that she can gain enough capital to make her business grow to the point where her daily income is increased.

loans.use: To gain business capital

loans.name: Nab

texts.en: Nab L. is a modest widowed woman of 53 years. She was married, but her husband died of senility years ago and she now has two children (one daughter and one son). Her daughter is married and lives separately, while her son is still single and works driving a motor taxi. Nab L. presently sells various fish in the market to earn a living. She is managing her investment very well and has attracted many regular clients because she is skilled at communicating with people. Nab L. is taking out this Kiva loan to help replace her son’s unattractive motor taxi and to buy additional fresh fish to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a motor taxi & buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Robert

texts.en: Robert is a charcoal vendor. He is 28 years old, single and lives in Barangay Sinili, Santiago City. He wants to have additional capital that he can use to buy more sacks of charcoal.  With this, he decided to borrow a loan amounting to PHP 5,000.00.  He is hoping that through his business, he can have an increase in income so he can continue to support his family with their needs.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Mah

texts.en:
Born in 1966, C. is married and has one child. She is proud that she and her husband were married in a traditional ceremony though she was forced into an early marriage and had to drop out of school. Though she is not educated, she is working very hard to see that her child and her brothers and sisters go to the highest level of education. With her previous loans from GHAPE, C. succeeded in growing and providing her community with cassava, beans, corn and ndjamadjama (huckleberry leaves, a popular green vegetable). Given a loan, she plans to buy fresh manure, fertilizer, seedlings and chemicals to expand and improve her farming. She also intends to buy chicks and raise them in order to generate income from the manure and meat.  She plans to repay the entire loan in 12 months. 
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works toward the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients

loans.use: Purchase of seedlings, fertilizer, feed, & chicks

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie manages a typical sari-sari store (community-based store) in the village of Sinili, S. City. She hopes that her business will grow and become a bigger store someday. Thus, she is requesting a loan of PHP 3,000 as additional capital.

Rosalie is blessed with three children namely: Mary Ann - 10 years old, an elementary student; Maricel - 8 years old, who is already in the third grade; and the youngest, Mizaaky - 3 years old. Rosalie wants all her children to finish with a college education and is hoping for them to have a successful life. With the support of her husband, Rosalie is doing her best for her family to have a better living.

loans.use: To use as business capital

loans.name: Anorhol

texts.ru: Мисирова Анорхол проживает в Варзобском районе. Возраст 63 года. Замужем, детей не имеет. Анорхол вместе с мужем занимается животноводством, т.к. пенсии им не хватает. Она откармливает и продает скот. Этим бизнесом занимается более 12 лет. Кредит, просит для покупки скота.
texts.en:
Anorhol M. lives in the Varzob district. She is 63 years old, married and has no children. Anorhol and her husband are involved in animal husbandry because pension is not enough to live on. She feeds and sells livestock. She has been involved in this business for over 12 years. She is requesting a loan for the purchase of livestock.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Elisha Kipyegon

texts.en: Elisha N. is 40 years old, married to Rhodah Chepkemoi, and blessed with three beautiful children. He operates his electronics business in Eldoret Town and most of his customers are from within Eldoret. Elisha has had seven other Loans from KADET, and intends to buy more stock like cables, switches, switch boxes, nails, screws and meter boxes to enable him to serve his customers more efficiently. With the profit he gets from his electronics shop, he has been able to provide basic needs for his family. Elisha intends to open a larger business premise in future, raise his standard of living, and build a permanent residence for his family. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy cables, switch boxes, socket outlets, one-way switches, nails, screws and meter boxes

loans.name: Kencha

texts.ru: Кенча Назарова проживает в районе Варзоб. Возраст 77 лет. Вдова, имеет 5 детей. Кенча более 15 лет занимается животноводством. Ей в этом помогают ее дети. Один из сыновей находится в России на заработках, он также высылает матери деньги. Клиентка просит кредит, для покупки дойной коровы и в дальнейшем будет продавать ее молоко.
texts.en:
Kencha N. lives in the Varzob district. She is 77 years old, a widow and has 5 children. Kencha has been involved in animal husbandry for over 15 years. Her children help her with this business. One of her sons works in Russia and sends money to his mother. Client is requesting a loan for the purchase of a dairy cow and plans to sell milk in the future.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a dairy cow

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sorm

texts.en:
Sorm S. is a domestic farmer, 47-years-old, who lives with her own small family in Siem Reap Province. Her husband is 66-year-old Mohn Duch, a farmer. On the other hand, her husband also catches fish for additional income. This couple has three children who are still young and who assist with their parent’s jobs when they are not studying.

The fishing season is coming; the river is full of fish. Sorm S. is looking for a loan for her husband to buy additional tools to successfully fish.
